section.title: Introduction to Trigonometric Identities

introduction.p: In this section, we will introduce the concept of trigonometric identities and work with several identities to prove that they are true.

subsection.title: Trigonometric Identities

assemblage.p: A trigonometric identitytrigonometric identity is a trigonometric equation that is true for every possible value of the input variable on which it is defined.

subsection.p: Identities are usually something that can be derived from definitions and relationships we already know. One identity that we are already familiar with is the Pythagorean Identity, which we derived from the definitions of sine and cosine. Recall the Pythagorean Identity states that for any angle \theta, \cos^2(\theta)+\sin^2(\theta)=1
In some cases, we can use trigonometric identities to simplify an expression. To do so, we can utilize the definitions and identities we have already established.

subsection.p: Sometimes a question may ask you to "prove the identity" or "establish the identity." This is the same idea as when you are asked to show that (x-1)^2 = x^2-2x+1. In this type of question, we must show the algebraic manipulations that demonstrate that the left and right side of the equation are in fact equal. You can think of a "prove the identity" problem as a simplification problem where you know the answer: you know what the end goal of the simplification should be and you just need to show the steps to get there.

There are two primary ways to prove identities:
Start with a known identity and algebraically manipulate both sides to get a new identity.
Start with one side of an identity you want to prove, then manipulate it using known identities to get the other side.
In this section, we will show examples using both strategies. It's important to note that there is no "standard algorithm" for proving identities! Every problem is a little different, but as you prove more identities you may begin to notice patterns that you can often use (such as writing tangent in terms of sine and cosine).

Something else to keep in mind is that when we are asked to prove a trigonometric identity, we do no treat the identity like an equation to solve - it isn't! Instead, we are trying to prove that the two expressions are equal, so we must take care to work with one side at a time rather than applying an operation simultaneously to both sides of the equation.

section.subsection:
The Double Angle Identities
Another useful type of trigonometric identities are the double angle identities. The double angle identities allow us to take trigonometric equations with 2\theta and replace them with trigonometric expressions containing just \theta. We will first derive the double angle formula for \sin(2\theta), and then the double angle formula for \cos(2\theta).
The first double angle identity that we will prove is \sin(2\theta) = 2\sin(\theta)\cos(\theta) which we will prove using the Law of Sines. We start by drawing a right triangle with one of the angles equal to \theta and a hypotenuse of length 1. We will label the other sides x and y and the other angle \alpha as shown below.
Because this is a right triangle, we know that
\begin{aligned} \cos(\alpha)=\dfrac{y}{1}=y\hspace{.5cm}\amp\text{and}\hspace{.5cm}\sin(\theta)=\dfrac{y}{1}=y \\ \sin(\alpha)=\dfrac{x}{1}=x\hspace{.5cm}\amp\text{and}\hspace{.5cm}\cos(\theta)=\dfrac{x}{1}=x \end{aligned}
Next, we attach a copy of this triangle to itself as though it has been reflected across the side labeled x:
Together, these two triangles form one large isoceles triangle; by the Law of Sines, this triangle gives
\dfrac{\sin(\alpha)}{1}=\dfrac{\sin(2\theta)}{2y}
or
\sin(2\theta)\cdot1=2y\cdot\sin(\alpha)
Using the fact that \sin(\alpha)=x=\cos(\theta) and y=\sin(\theta), this becomes simply \sin(2\theta)=2\sin(\theta)\cos(\theta) as desired.
\sin(2\theta) = 2\sin(\theta)\cos(\theta)
The second double angle identity is \cos(2\theta)=\cos^2(\theta)-\sin^2(\theta) and can be proved similarly, using the Law of Cosines instead of the Law of Sines. We will reuse the same triangles as above:
By the Law of Cosines,
\begin{aligned} (2y)^2 \amp= 1^2+1^2-2(1)(1)\cos(2\theta) \\ 4y^2 \amp= 2-2\cos(2\theta) \\ \cos(2\theta) \amp= 1-2y^2 \end{aligned}
But from the original right triangles, we know that y=\sin(\theta), so y^2=\sin^2(\theta). This, combined with the identity \cos^2(\theta)=1-\sin^2(\theta), gives
\begin{aligned} \cos(2\theta) \amp= 1-2y^2 \\ \amp= 1-2\sin^2(\theta) \\ \amp= 1-\sin^2(\theta)-\sin^2(\theta) \\ \amp= \cos^2(\theta)-\sin^2(\theta) \end{aligned}
as claimed.
\cos(2\theta) = \cos^2(\theta)-\sin^2(\theta)
Together, these form the double angle identities.
The Double Angle Identities
\sin(2\theta) \amp = 2\sin(\theta)\cos(\theta)
\cos(2\theta) \amp = \cos^2(\theta) - \sin^2(\theta)

subsection.title: Solving Trigonometric Equations with Identities
subsection.p: In the last chapter, we solved basic trigonometric equations. Using identities, we can now explore different techniques to solve more complicated trig equations. Building from what we already know makes this a much easier task.

statement.p: Solve the trigonometric equation \cos^2(\theta)-2\sin(\theta)+2=0 for all values of \theta.

solution.p: Because this equation has both the square of cosine and a sine, we cannot factor this like we have in the past. However, we have a trigonometric identity for \cos^2(\theta) in terms of sine: \cos^2(\theta)=1-\sin^2(\theta) Substituting this into our equation, we can simplify and then factor.

This means that either -\sin(\theta)+1=0 or \sin(\theta)+3=0. It cannot be the case that \sin(\theta)+3=0 since there is no solution to \sin(\theta)=-3. The other equation, -\sin(\theta)+1=0, implies that \sin(\theta)=1, which gives an initial solution of \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}. Since sine is 2\pi-periodic, the solution set is \theta=\frac{\pi}{2}+2\pi k \hspace{.5cm}\text{for any integer }k
